case_name: Income-tax Officer, Companies Circle 1(4), Bombay v. Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, Companies Circle 1 4, Bombay, computed the respondent-company's total income for the assessment year 1952-53 at Rs. 23,596 and brought that amount to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Companies Circle 1  4 , Bombay, companyputed the respondent-companys total income for the assessment year 1952-53 at Rs. 23,596 and brought that amount to tax.

facts.text: The respondent-company distributed Rs. 2,66,788 as dividend in the previous year.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent- companypany had, however, distributed Rs. 2,66,788 as dividend in the previous year.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer by his order dated 27th July 1955 levied additional tax on the excess dividend declared by the respondent-company and ordered payment of Rs. 33,348-8-0 as additional tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, by his order dated the 27th July, 1955, levied an additional tax on the excess dividend declared by the respondent-company and ordered the companypany to pay as additional tax on the excess dividend Rs. 33,348-8-0.

facts.text: The respondent-company complied with the order and paid the additional tax.

anchor.surface_text: The order was companyplied with.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax held that the levy of tax on excess dividend was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, it appears that the Bombay High Court in Khatau Makanji Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax held that the levy of tax on excess dividend was illegal.

facts.text: The respondent-company on September 28, 1956 applied to the Income-tax Officer for refund of the tax paid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company, on September 28, 1956, applied to the Income-tax Officer for refund of the tax paid.

facts.text: The application expressly stated that the order be rectified under section 35 of the Indian Income-tax Act and an order for refund be made.

anchor.surface_text: It was number expressly stated in the application that the order be rectified under section 35 of the Indian Income-tax Act, and an order for refund be made.

facts.text: The request was that the tax be declared unlawfully collected and refunded, which meant a request for rectification.

anchor.surface_text: But numberIncome-tax Officer is entitled to refund tax which has been lawfully imposed and companylected. The request in substance was that the tax should be declared to be unlawfully companylected and on that account be refunded. That companyld only mean a request for rectification.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer by order dated 2nd November 1957 declined the request for refund.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated the 2nd November, 1957, the Income-tax Officer declined to accede to the request.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer stated that the assessment for 1952-53 was completed before the Bombay High Court judgment in Khatau Makanji case.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that the assessment for the year 1952-53 was companypleted a long time back and before the judgment in the case of Khatau Makanji Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd. was pronounced by the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Respondent-company moved Commissioner of Income-tax under section 33A to revise the ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Income-tax Officer the respondent companypany moved the Commissioner of Income-tax under section 33A by an application to revise the order.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax rejected the application.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax rejected the application,

facts.text: Respondent-company moved Bombay High Court under article 226 for order compelling ITO to revise order dated 2nd November 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Commissioner, the respondent companypany moved the High Court of Bombay on the original side under article 226 of the Constitution, for an order companypelling the Income-tax Officer to revise the order dated 2nd November, 1957, of the first respondent and issue direction in pursuance thereof.

facts.text: High Court granted the application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court granted the application.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment holds that levy of additional tax was illegal in view of its judgment in CIT v. Khatau Makanji Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that, in view of the judgment of this companyrt in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Khatau Makanji Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd., the levy of an additional tax was illegal.

facts.text: Before High Court, it was urged that no application for rectification under section 35 was presented by respondent-company.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged, however, before the High Court that numberapplication for rectification under section 35 of the Income-tax Act was presented by the respondent-company,

facts.text: High Court rejected the contention that no section 35 application was made.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention principally on the ground that the income-tax authorities had themselves treated the application as one under section 35

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court was right in directing refund of illegally collected tax.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in making the order, directing the Commissioner to refund the amount of tax which was illegally companylected.

facts.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.

holdings.text: There is numberdoubt that, in view of the judgment of this companyrt in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Khatau Makanji Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd., the levy of an additional tax was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent of this Court in CIT v. Khatau Makanji Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd. renders the levy illegal.

holdings.text: The request in substance was that the tax should be declared to be unlawfully companylected and on that account be refunded. That companyld only mean a request for rectification.

anchor.surface_text: But numberIncome-tax Officer is entitled to refund tax which has been lawfully imposed and companylected. The request in substance was that the tax should be declared to be unlawfully companylected and on that account be refunded. That companyld only mean a request for rectification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit request to declare tax unlawful and refund equates to seeking rectification of assessment order under section 35.

holdings.text: the income-tax authorities had themselves treated the application as one under section 35 and had rejected the same on the merits. As already pointed out, the application to the Income-tax Officer was one in which a request for rectification of the order was implicit and the Commissioner in dealing with the application for refund treated that application in that light.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention principally on the ground that the income-tax authorities had themselves treated the application as one under section 35 and had rejected the same on the merits. As already pointed out, the application to the Income-tax Officer was one in which a request for rectification of the order was implicit and the Commissioner in dealing with the application for refund treated that application in that light.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax authorities and Commissioner treated refund application as section 35 rectification request and addressed it on merits; request for rectification was implicit in the application.

holdings.text: In our view, the High Court was right in making the order, directing the Commissioner to refund the amount of tax which was illegally companylected.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in making the order, directing the Commissioner to refund the amount of tax which was illegally companylected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given illegality of levy and proper rectification procedure under section 35, High Court correctly directed refund of illegally collected tax.
